Background.text:
Lower extremity equivalent of
Galeazzi fracture

Components.text:
Fibula fracture (anywhere from head or as far down as 6cm above ankle joint)
Deltoid ligament rupture or medial malleolus avulsion fracture
Injury then directed upward and laterally tearing interosseous membrane and anterior inferior tibiofibular ligament
May involve posterior tibiofibular ligament or posterior malleolar fracture

Fibula fracture (anywhere from head or as far down as 6cm above ankle joint)
Deltoid ligament rupture or medial malleolus avulsion fracture
Injury then directed upward and laterally tearing interosseous membrane and anterior inferior tibiofibular ligament
May involve posterior tibiofibular ligament or posterior malleolar fracture

Clinical_Features.text: Results from external rotation force applied to foot

Distal_Leg_Fracture_Types.text:
Tibial plateau fracture
Tibial shaft fracture
Pilon fracture
Maisonneuve fracture
Tibia fracture (peds)
Ankle fracture
Ankle fracture (peds)
Tillaux fracture
Foot and toe fractures

Tibial plateau fracture
Tibial shaft fracture
Pilon fracture
Maisonneuve fracture
Tibia fracture (peds)
Ankle fracture
Ankle fracture (peds)
Tillaux fracture
Foot and toe fractures

Evaluation.text:
Assess distal pulse, motor, and sensation
Inspect skin for signs of open fracture
Long leg film that includes ankle
Increase in medial clear space of ankle joint
Tibiofibular clear space widened >5mm
High fibular fracture
Signs of
syndesmotic injury

General_Fracture_Management.text:
Acute pain management
Open fractures
require immediate IV antibiotics and urgent surgical washout
Neurovascular compromise from fracture requires emergent reduction and/or orthopedic intervention
Consider risk for
compartment syndrome

Specific_Management.text:
Long leg posterior splint
with reduction of medial ankle and syndesmotic clear space

require immediate IV antibiotics and urgent surgical washout

Specific_Management.text:
Long leg posterior splint
with reduction of medial ankle and syndesmotic clear space

Long leg posterior splint
with reduction of medial ankle and syndesmotic clear space

Disposition.text:
Depends on degree of associated ankle injury
If splinted and stabilized, can be discharged after consultation with ortho
[1]
Will need close follow-up for likely operative repair
Admit for:
[2]
Open fracture
Signs of neurovascular injury
Concern for
compartment syndrome

Specialty_Management.text: Usually requires surgical intervention (syndesmotic screws; proximal fibular fracture usually requires no fixation)
Usually requires surgical intervention (syndesmotic screws; proximal fibular fracture usually requires no fixation)

See_Also.text:
Ankle syndesmosis injury
Distal leg fractures
